prior_works.title: On the Power of the Weisfeiler-Leman Algorithm
prior_works.authors: Martin Grohe, Daniel Neuen, Pascal Schweitzer
prior_works.role: Theoretical foundation for WL hierarchy and its limitations
prior_works.relationship_sentence: This work formalizes the k-WL hierarchy and its distinguishing power, providing the baseline against which r-loopy WL’s incomparability with fixed k-WL is established.

prior_works.title: Lovász Meets Weisfeiler and Leman
prior_works.authors: Holger Dell, Martin Grohe, Gaurav Rattan
prior_works.relationship_sentence: It proves that 1-WL distinguishes graphs exactly via counts of homomorphisms from all trees, a key stepping stone that the new r-ℓWL extends from trees to cactus graphs.

prior_works.title: Neural Message Passing for Quantum Chemistry
prior_works.authors: Justin Gilmer, Samuel S. Schoenholz, Patrick F. Riley, Oriol Vinyals, George E. Dahl
prior_works.relationship_sentence: The r-ℓMPNN architecture is instantiated within the MPNN paradigm introduced here, translating the r-ℓWL test into a practical neural message-passing scheme.

prior_works.title: How Powerful are Graph Neural Networks?
prior_works.authors: Keyulu Xu, Weihua Hu, Jure Leskovec, Stefanie Jegelka
prior_works.relationship_sentence: By characterizing standard MPNNs (e.g., GIN) as 1-WL-powerful, this paper motivates the need for architectures surpassing 1-WL and frames the contribution of r-ℓMPNN as a principled expressivity lift.

prior_works.title: Weisfeiler and Leman Go Neural: Higher-Order Graph Neural Networks
prior_works.authors: Christopher Morris, Martin Ritzert, Matthias Fey, William L. Hamilton, Jan Eric Lenssen, Gaurav Rattan, Martin Grohe
prior_works.relationship_sentence: This establishes the correspondence between higher-order GNNs and k-WL, providing the primary comparator for the claim that r-ℓWL is incomparable with any fixed k-WL.

prior_works.title: Homomorphisms are a Good Basis for Counting Graphs
prior_works.authors: Radu Curticapean, Holger Dell, Dániel Marx
prior_works.role: Theory of homomorphism counting as a unifying basis
prior_works.relationship_sentence: It underpins the homomorphism-counting viewpoint adopted by r-ℓWL, framing cactus-graph homomorphism counting as a principled target beyond trees.

prior_works.title: Weisfeiler-Lehman Graph Kernels
prior_works.authors: Nino Shervashidze, Pascal Schweitzer, Erik Jan van Leeuwen, Kurt Mehlhorn, Karsten M. Borgwardt
prior_works.relationship_sentence: By operationalizing WL refinements for learning, this work bridges WL theory and practical graph representation, a bridge that r-ℓWL/MPNN extends with loopy refinements and cycle-counting capacity.

synthesis_narrative: The paper’s core contribution—a loopy refinement of Weisfeiler–Leman (r-ℓWL) that enables counting cycles up to length r+2 and homomorphisms of cactus graphs—builds on a convergence of WL theory, homomorphism-counting characterizations, and GNN expressivity results. Grohe–Neuen–Schweitzer precisely chart the power of k-WL, positioning it as the canonical hierarchy for graph isomorphism testing; this provides the formal backdrop for demonstrating r-ℓWL’s incomparability with any fixed k-WL. Dell–Grohe–Rattan’s seminal link between 1-WL and counts of homomorphisms from trees is the conceptual hinge the authors extend: r-ℓWL lifts the homomorphism-counting frontier from trees to cactus graphs, thereby strictly enriching the counting repertoire without resorting to higher-order WL tensors. The homomorphism basis developed by Curticapean–Dell–Marx justifies hom-counts as the right algebraic currency for graph statistics, guiding the selection of cactus motifs as a tractable, informative class. On the learning side, Gilmer et al.’s MPNN framework and Xu et al.’s GIN characterization cement the 1-WL ceiling for standard message passing, motivating architectural changes. Morris et al. show how higher-order GNNs align with k-WL, furnishing the main comparator for the new hierarchy. Finally, Shervashidze et al. demonstrate how WL refinements translate to effective learning machinery, a pathway r-ℓMPNN follows while adding loopy refinements that provably enable cycle and cactus homomorphism counting, and empirically yield strong performance on sparse graphs.
